metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Model mathematically time dilation and length contraction at speeds approaching c using the equations: t = γt₀ and L = L₀/γ where γ = 1/√(1 − v²/c²)

lorentz_factor_formula.name: Lorentz Factor Formula
lorentz_factor_formula.correct: The Lorentz factor γ = 1/√(1 − v²/c²) quantifies relativistic effects. At rest γ = 1; as v approaches c, γ approaches infinity.

γ = √(1 − v²/c²).error: Missing the reciprocal. That expression is under the dividing line.
γ = √(1 − v²/c²).fix: γ = 1/√(1 − v²/c²). The whole square root is in the denominator.
γ = √(1 − v²/c²).action: Calculate for v = 0: should get γ = 1, not γ = 1.

γ = 1/√(1 + v²/c²).error: Wrong sign. It's minus, not plus.
γ = 1/√(1 + v²/c²).fix: γ = 1/√(1 − v²/c²). Subtraction under the square root.
γ = 1/√(1 + v²/c²).action: Check: as v → c, denominator → 0, so γ → ∞. Plus sign wouldn't do that.

γ = (1 − v²/c²).fix: γ = 1/√(1 − v²/c²). Square root of the bracket, then take reciprocal.
γ = (1 − v²/c²).action: Write out step by step: first (1 − v²/c²), then √ of that, then 1 divided by result.

persistent.gap: You're not remembering the structure of the Lorentz factor formula.
persistent.action: Write γ = 1/√(1 − v²/c²) five times. Then calculate γ for v = 0, 0.5c, and 0.9c.

lorentz_factor_behaviour.name: Lorentz Factor Behaviour
lorentz_factor_behaviour.formula: γ ≥ 1 always; γ → ∞ as v → c
lorentz_factor_behaviour.correct: The Lorentz factor equals 1 at rest, increases with speed, and approaches infinity as speed approaches c.

equals zero at rest.action: Substitute v = 0 into the formula and verify γ = 1.

decreases with speed.fix: As v increases, (1 − v²/c²) gets smaller, so 1/√(smaller) gets bigger.
decreases with speed.action: Calculate γ at 0.5c and 0.9c. The 0.9c value should be larger.

approaches zero as v approaches c.fix: As v → c, the denominator √(1 − v²/c²) → 0, so γ = 1/0 → ∞.
approaches zero as v approaches c.action: This is why objects with mass can't reach light speed—they'd need infinite energy.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how the Lorentz factor varies with speed.
persistent.action: Plot γ vs v from 0 to 0.99c. Note: γ increases rapidly near c.

proper_time_definition.name: Proper Time Definition
proper_time_definition.formula: t₀ = time in frame where events occur at same location
proper_time_definition.correct: Proper time t₀ is the time interval between two events measured in the reference frame where both events occur at the same point in space.

the time measured by a moving observer.error: Motion is relative. Proper time is about spatial location, not motion.
the time measured by a moving observer.fix: Proper time is measured when both events happen at the same place in that frame.
the time measured by a moving observer.action: Ask: do the two events occur at the same spatial location in this frame?

the longest time interval measured.error: Opposite. Proper time is always the shortest interval.
the longest time interval measured.fix: Proper time t₀ is always less than or equal to dilated time t.
the longest time interval measured.action: Check formula: t = γt₀ and γ ≥ 1, so t ≥ t₀.

the time measured by a stationary observ.error: 'Stationary' is relative. Use spatial coincidence instead.
the time measured by a stationary observ.fix: Proper time is measured when events happen at the same location in that frame.
the time measured by a stationary observ.action: Both observers claim to be stationary. Focus on whether events are at same place.

persistent.gap: You're not identifying proper time correctly.
persistent.action: For any scenario, ask: 'In which frame do both events occur at the same spatial location?' That frame measures proper time.

proper_length_definition.name: Proper Length Definition
proper_length_definition.formula: L₀ = length measured when at rest relative to object
proper_length_definition.correct: Proper length L₀ is the length of an object measured in the reference frame where the object is at rest.

the length measured by a moving observer.error: Opposite. Moving observer measures contracted length.
the length measured by a moving observer.fix: Proper length is measured when the object is at rest relative to you.
the length measured by a moving observer.action: If the object is moving past you, you measure contracted length, not proper length.

the shortest length measured.error: Opposite. Proper length is the longest length.
the shortest length measured.fix: Proper length L₀ is always greater than or equal to contracted length L.
the shortest length measured.action: Check formula: L = L₀/γ and γ ≥ 1, so L ≤ L₀.

the length in any inertial frame.error: Only in the rest frame of the object.
the length in any inertial frame.fix: Proper length is measured in the frame where the object isn't moving.
the length in any inertial frame.action: Different frames measure different lengths. Proper length is the rest frame value.

persistent.gap: You're not identifying proper length correctly.
persistent.action: Ask: 'Is the object at rest in this frame?' If yes, that frame measures proper length.

time_dilation_formula.name: Time Dilation Formula
time_dilation_formula.correct: Time dilation: t = γt₀. Observer P observes D's clock running slow. D's seconds are stretched, so fewer pass, so D ages less (as observed by P).

t = t₀/γ.error: Inverted. That's the length contraction structure.
t = t₀/γ.fix: Time dilation: t = γt₀ (multiply). Length contraction: L = L₀/γ (divide).
t = t₀/γ.action: Dilated time is LARGER than proper time. Multiplying by γ ≥ 1 makes it larger.

t₀ = γt.error: Wrong arrangement. t₀ is the smaller value.
t₀ = γt.fix: t = γt₀ means dilated time = γ × proper time.
t₀ = γt.action: Proper time is always smallest. It gets multiplied by γ to give larger dilated time.

t = t₀ − γ.error: Wrong operation. It's multiplication, not subtraction.
t = t₀ − γ.fix: t = γt₀ means γ multiplies t₀.
t = t₀ − γ.action: Check units: γ is dimensionless, t₀ is time, so γ × t₀ = time.

persistent.gap: You're not remembering the time dilation formula correctly.
persistent.action: Write t = γt₀ ten times. Remember: dilated = gamma × proper.

time_dilation_interpretation.name: Time Dilation Interpretation
time_dilation_interpretation.formula: P observes D's clock running slow
time_dilation_interpretation.correct: Time dilation is observational, not experiential. D experiences normal time; dilation is what P OBSERVES about D's clock. D's seconds appear stretched to P.

D experiences their time running slowly.error: No one experiences their own time as dilated.
D experiences their time running slowly.fix: D experiences their own time as completely normal. Dilation is P's observation about D.
D experiences their time running slowly.action: You never feel your own time slowing. You always experience normal proper time.

dilated time means more seconds pass.error: Opposite. D's seconds are stretched, so fewer pass.
dilated time means more seconds pass.fix: t = γt₀ means more P-seconds pass than D-seconds. D ages LESS.
dilated time means more seconds pass.action: If D's seconds are stretched (longer), fewer fit in the same interval. D ages less.

time dilation makes D older than P.error: Opposite. D ages less than P (as observed by P).
time dilation makes D older than P.fix: Moving clocks run slow → D's clock shows less time → D is younger.
time dilation makes D older than P.action: Remember: moving clocks run slow. Less time on D's clock = D ages less.

persistent.gap: You're confusing who experiences what in time dilation.
persistent.action: Key insight: dilation is OBSERVATIONAL. Everyone experiences their own time as normal. P observes D's clock running slow.

length_contraction_formula.name: Length Contraction Formula
length_contraction_formula.correct: Length contraction: L = L₀/γ. Moving objects appear shorter in the direction of motion when observed from another frame.

L = γL₀.error: Inverted. That would make L larger, not smaller.
L = γL₀.fix: L = L₀/γ. Dividing by γ ≥ 1 makes L smaller than L₀.
L = γL₀.action: Contraction means shorter. Dividing by γ > 1 makes it shorter.

L₀ = L/γ.error: Wrong arrangement. L₀ is the larger value.
L₀ = L/γ.fix: L = L₀/γ means contracted length = proper length ÷ γ.
L₀ = L/γ.action: Proper length is always largest. It gets divided by γ to give smaller contracted length.

L = L₀ − γ.error: Wrong operation. It's division, not subtraction.
L = L₀ − γ.fix: L = L₀/γ means L₀ divided by γ.
L = L₀ − γ.action: Check units: γ is dimensionless, L₀ is length, so L₀/γ = length.

persistent.gap: You're not remembering the length contraction formula correctly.
persistent.action: Write L = L₀/γ ten times. Remember: contracted = proper ÷ gamma.

contraction_direction.name: Direction of Length Contraction
contraction_direction.formula: Contraction only in direction of motion
contraction_direction.correct: Length contraction occurs ONLY in the direction of relative motion. Perpendicular dimensions are unchanged.

in all directions equally.error: Only in the direction of motion.
in all directions equally.fix: A moving rocket contracts in length but not in height or width.
in all directions equally.action: Visualise: a rocket moving horizontally gets shorter horizontally, same height.

perpendicular to motion.error: Opposite. Contraction is parallel to motion.
perpendicular to motion.fix: If motion is along x-axis, only x-dimension contracts. y and z unchanged.
perpendicular to motion.action: Draw a moving rectangle. Only the dimension along velocity shrinks.

in the direction perpendicular to veloci.error: Contraction is parallel to velocity, not perpendicular.
in the direction perpendicular to veloci.fix: Motion along x → x contracts. y and z dimensions stay the same.
in the direction perpendicular to veloci.action: Think of a train: it gets shorter front-to-back, but stays same width.

persistent.action: Rule: contraction is PARALLEL to motion. Draw diagrams showing this.

identifying_proper_time_scenarios.name: Identifying Proper Time in Scenarios
identifying_proper_time_scenarios.formula: Events at same spatial location → proper time
identifying_proper_time_scenarios.correct: To identify proper time: find the frame where both events occur at the same point in space. That observer measures proper time.

the frame of Earth observers.error: Earth isn't automatically the proper time frame.
the frame of Earth observers.fix: Ask: do both events (e.g., particle creation and decay) occur at same place in Earth's frame?
the frame of Earth observers.action: For a moving particle, Earth sees events at different locations → Earth measures dilated time.

the frame measuring more time.error: Opposite. Proper time is the shortest interval.
the frame measuring more time.fix: Proper time t₀ is always the minimum. Dilated time t = γt₀ is larger.
the frame measuring more time.action: If you calculated two times, the smaller one is proper time.

whichever observer is at rest.error: 'At rest' is relative. Both observers can claim to be at rest.
whichever observer is at rest.fix: Focus on: in which frame do both events occur at the same spatial location?
whichever observer is at rest.action: Forget 'at rest'. Ask where the events happen spatially in each frame.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly identifying which frame measures proper time.
persistent.action: For every problem: identify the two events, then ask which frame sees them at the same place.

identifying_proper_length_scenarios.name: Identifying Proper Length in Scenarios
identifying_proper_length_scenarios.correct: To identify proper length: find the frame where the object being measured is at rest. That observer measures proper length.

the frame measuring shorter length.error: Opposite. Proper length is the longest measurement.
the frame measuring shorter length.fix: L₀ is always the maximum. Contracted length L = L₀/γ is smaller.
the frame measuring shorter length.action: If you calculated two lengths, the larger one is proper length.

the Earth's frame for all objects.fix: For a moving spaceship, the spaceship's frame measures proper length of the spaceship.
the Earth's frame for all objects.action: Ask: is the object at rest in Earth's frame or moving through it?

the moving observer's frame.error: It's the frame where the object is at rest, not where observer is 'moving'.
the moving observer's frame.fix: If measuring a platform, Earth's frame measures proper length. If measuring a rocket, rocket's frame does.
the moving observer's frame.action: Identify the object. Find the frame where that object isn't moving.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly identifying which frame measures proper length.
persistent.action: For every problem: identify what object is being measured, then ask where that object is at rest.

relativistic_symmetry.name: Symmetry of Special Relativity
relativistic_symmetry.formula: Both observers see other's clock as slow
relativistic_symmetry.correct: Both observers see the OTHER's clock as running slow. This is symmetric. The paradox is resolved when acceleration occurs.

only one observer sees time dilation.error: Both observers see the other's clock running slow.
only one observer sees time dilation.fix: P sees D's clock slow. D sees P's clock slow. Both are correct in their frames.
only one observer sees time dilation.action: Symmetry is key. Neither frame is privileged in special relativity.

the moving observer's clock is actually.error: 'Actually' assumes absolute time, which doesn't exist.
the moving observer's clock is actually.fix: Both observations are equally valid. There's no absolute answer until frames are compared.
the moving observer's clock is actually.action: Motion is relative. Both can claim the other is moving and both are correct.

Earth's measurements are the 'real' ones.error: No frame is privileged in special relativity.
Earth's measurements are the 'real' ones.fix: Earth's frame isn't special. All inertial frames are equally valid.
Earth's measurements are the 'real' ones.action: Relativity means NO preferred frame. All inertial observers are equal.

persistent.gap: You're treating one frame as privileged over another.
persistent.action: Key principle: all inertial frames are equally valid. Both see the other's clock as slow.

lorentz_factor.title: Understanding the Lorentz Factor
lorentz_factor.instructions: Complete the statements about the Lorentz factor and its properties.

sentences.text: The Lorentz factor is calculated using the formula γ = {{d1}}, where v is the relative velocity and c is the {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Check: γ should equal 1 when v = 0

d2.tooltip: The universal speed limit in the universe

sentences.text: When an object is at rest (v = 0), the Lorentz factor equals {{d3}}. As the speed approaches c, the Lorentz factor approaches {{d4}}.

d4.tooltip: What happens when the denominator approaches zero?

sentences.text: The Lorentz factor is {{d5}} quantity that is always greater than or equal to {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: γ has no units because it's a ratio

proper_time.title: Defining Proper Time
proper_time.instructions: Complete the statements about proper time and how to identify it.

sentences.text: Proper time (t₀) is defined as the time interval between two events measured in a reference frame where both events occur at the {{d1}} in space.

d1.tooltip: Spatial coincidence is the key criterion

sentences.text: The observer who measures proper time has both events occurring at {{d2}} relative to them. This makes proper time the {{d3}} time interval any observer can measure.

d2.tooltip: Think: where do the events happen in this frame?

d3.tooltip: Compare t₀ and t = γt₀ when γ ≥ 1

sentences.text: For a particle created and then decaying while moving through a laboratory, the {{d4}} frame measures proper time because both events occur at the {{d5}}.

d4.tooltip: In which frame does the particle stay in one place?

d5.tooltip: The particle is at rest in its own frame

time_dilation.title: Understanding Time Dilation
time_dilation.instructions: Complete the statements about the time dilation formula and its meaning.

sentences.text: The time dilation formula is t = {{d1}}, where t is the dilated time and t₀ is the proper time.

d1.tooltip: Dilated time is larger than proper time

sentences.text: Time dilation is {{d2}}, not experiential. The moving object D experiences their own time as completely {{d3}}.

d2.tooltip: Dilation is what P observes about D's clock

d3.tooltip: No one experiences their own time as abnormal

sentences.text: When observer P watches moving object D, P observes D's clock running {{d4}}. This means D's seconds appear {{d5}} to P, so fewer of them pass.

d5.tooltip: Dilated = stretched. Longer seconds = fewer pass.

length_contraction.title: Understanding Length Contraction
length_contraction.instructions: Complete the statements about length contraction and proper length.

sentences.text: Proper length (L₀) is the length of an object measured in a reference frame where the object is at {{d1}}.

d1.tooltip: The object isn't moving relative to this observer

sentences.text: The length contraction formula is L = {{d2}}, which means contracted length is always {{d3}} than proper length.

d2.tooltip: Dividing by γ ≥ 1 makes L smaller

sentences.text: Length contraction occurs only in the direction {{d4}} to the relative motion. Dimensions perpendicular to motion remain {{d5}}.

d4.tooltip: A moving rocket shortens along its length of travel

lorentz_factor.title: Applying the Lorentz Factor
lorentz_factor.instructions: Apply your understanding of the Lorentz factor to practical scenarios.

sentences.text: For an object travelling at 0.6c, the value of v²/c² equals {{d1}}, and after subtracting from 1 and taking the square root then reciprocal, γ = {{d2}}.
At everyday speeds like a jet aircraft, the Lorentz factor is extremely close to {{d3}}, which is why relativistic effects are {{d4}} in daily life.

d4.tooltip: γ ≈ 1 means almost no relativistic effects

sentences.text: A particle accelerator speeds particles to 0.99c, giving γ ≈ 7. Reaching 0.999c increases γ to approximately {{d5}}. This rapid increase explains why reaching c requires {{d6}} energy.

proper_time.title: Identifying Proper Time in Practice
proper_time.instructions: Apply proper time concepts to real-world scenarios.

sentences.text: An astronaut's heartbeat while travelling in a spacecraft is measured. The {{d1}} measures proper time because the heart beats at the {{d2}} in their frame.

d1.tooltip: Who sees the heart in one location?

d2.tooltip: The astronaut's heart doesn't move relative to them

sentences.text: A cosmic ray muon is created and decays while travelling toward Earth. Earth observers measure {{d3}} time because the muon moves between {{d4}} in Earth's frame.

d3.tooltip: Events at different places → dilated time

d4.tooltip: Creation and decay happen at different places in Earth's frame

sentences.text: Both observers agree on the {{d5}}, but disagree on the time elapsed. This is because time measurement depends on the observer's {{d6}}.

time_dilation.title: Applying Time Dilation
time_dilation.instructions: Apply time dilation to solve problems and interpret results.

sentences.text: A particle with proper half-life 2.2 μs travels at 0.995c (γ = 10). An Earth observer measures its half-life as {{d1}} μs because time is {{d2}} in Earth's frame.

d2.tooltip: Earth sees the particle's clock running slow

sentences.text: From the particle's perspective, it experiences {{d3}} of proper time, feeling completely normal. The dilation is what {{d4}} observes about the particle's clock.

d3.tooltip: The particle measures its own proper time

d4.tooltip: Dilation is observational from the other frame

sentences.text: The reason more muons reach Earth's surface than classical physics predicts is that Earth observers measure the muon's lifetime as {{d5}}, allowing them to travel {{d6}} before decaying.

d5.tooltip: t = γt₀ gives a larger value

d6.tooltip: More time = more distance at the same speed

length_contraction.title: Applying Length Contraction
length_contraction.instructions: Apply length contraction to solve problems and interpret results.

sentences.text: A 100 m rocket travels at 0.8c (γ = 1.67). An observer on Earth measures its length as approximately {{d1}} m because the rocket is {{d2}} relative to Earth.
A spaceship crew measures their ship as 200 m long. They measure {{d3}} for their ship because the ship is at {{d4}} relative to them.

d3.tooltip: The ship isn't moving in the crew's frame

d4.tooltip: Crew and ship are stationary relative to each other

sentences.text: From the muon's reference frame, the distance to Earth's surface is {{d5}} compared to Earth's measurement. This is because the distance is {{d6}} in the muon's frame.

d5.tooltip: L = L₀/γ gives a smaller value

d6.tooltip: Earth is moving relative to the muon

lorentz_factor.title: Mastering the Lorentz Factor
lorentz_factor.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of the Lorentz factor and its implications.

sentences.text: The reason γ appears in both time dilation (t = γt₀) and length contraction (L = L₀/γ) is that space and time are {{d1}}. The different operations (multiply vs divide) reflect that time {{d2}} while length contracts.

d2.tooltip: Opposite effects on time and length

sentences.text: At 0.866c, γ = 2, meaning relativistic effects are {{d3}}. A clock ticks at {{d4}} the rate, and lengths are {{d5}} as long, compared to rest values.

d4.tooltip: Observed clock rate = 1/γ of proper rate

sentences.text: Particle accelerators must be designed longer than classical physics suggests because particles measure the accelerator length as {{d6}} due to length contraction in their frame.

d6.tooltip: From particle's view, accelerator is contracted

proper_time.title: Mastering Proper Time Concepts
proper_time.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of proper time and frame analysis.

sentences.text: The key question for identifying proper time is: 'In which frame do both events occur at the {{d1}}?' The answer determines who measures {{d2}} time.

d1.tooltip: Spatial coincidence is the defining criterion

sentences.text: For GPS satellites, the clocks must be adjusted because Earth observers measure {{d3}} time on the satellite clocks. Without correction, GPS positions would drift by approximately {{d4}} per day.

d3.tooltip: Earth sees satellite clocks running slow

sentences.text: A common misconception is that time dilation means D 'feels' time passing slowly. In reality, D experiences {{d5}} time; the dilation is purely what {{d6}} observes.

d5.tooltip: Everyone experiences their own time as normal

d6.tooltip: Dilation is observational from the other frame

time_dilation.title: Mastering Time Dilation
time_dilation.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of time dilation and its symmetry.

sentences.text: Special relativity is symmetric: P observes D's clock running slow, AND D observes {{d1}} clock running slow. Both observations are {{d2}} in their respective frames.

d1.tooltip: Symmetry means both see the other's clock as slow

d2.tooltip: No frame is privileged in special relativity

sentences.text: The twin paradox is resolved by recognising that one twin must {{d3}} to return, which breaks the symmetry. The travelling twin ends up {{d4}} than the stay-at-home twin.

d4.tooltip: Less proper time elapsed for the traveller

sentences.text: When we say 'moving clocks run slow,' we mean P {{d5}} D's clock as running slow. The statement 'D's dilated time means D ages more' is {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: It's an observation, not an experience

d6.tooltip: Dilated seconds are stretched; fewer pass; D ages LESS

length_contraction.title: Mastering Length Contraction
length_contraction.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of length contraction and its applications.

sentences.text: Time dilation and length contraction give {{d1}} explanations for the same phenomenon. Earth explains muon survival via {{d2}}; the muon explains it via {{d3}}.

d2.tooltip: Earth sees the muon's lifetime as increased

d3.tooltip: Muon sees the distance as shortened

sentences.text: If a 10 km distance contracts to 1 km for a particle (γ = 10), the particle also measures Earth clocks as running {{d4}}. The contracted distance and dilated Earth time give the {{d5}} relative velocity.

d5.tooltip: Both frames agree on relative velocity

sentences.text: A moving ruler appears contracted only in the direction of {{d6}}. If a square moves horizontally, it appears as a {{d7}} because width contracts but height doesn't.

d7.tooltip: Horizontal dimension shrinks; vertical stays same
